content: The "Fee Repeal and Expanded Access Act of 2007" amends the Federal Lands Recreation Enhancement Act by changing the short title and recreation fee authorities. Beginning January 1, 2008, the Secretary of the Interior may establish and collect fees for admission to National Park units and for the use of specific facilities at Federal recreational lands. The authorized facilities include developed campgrounds with tent or trailer spaces and picnic tables. The Secretary of the Interior may establish fees for admission to National Park units and specific facilities at Federal recreational lands, including developed campgrounds with tent or trailer spaces, picnic tables, drinking water, access roads, fee collection, visitor protection, refuse containers, toilet facilities, and campfire devices. Specialized facilities at boat launches may also be used, along with rental options for cabins, boats, and other amenities. The Secretary of the Interior may establish fees for admission to National Park units and specific facilities at Federal recreational lands, including developed campgrounds, picnic areas, and swimming sites with various amenities. Admission fees cannot be charged for individuals under 16 years of age. The Secretary may establish fees for admission to National Park units and specific facilities at Federal recreational lands, excluding Denali National Park and Preserve. Fees cannot be charged for Federal recreational land managed by the Bureau of Land Management or the Commissioner of Reclamation. The Secretary must establish a minimum number of fees and avoid collecting multiple fees for various activities. Before setting a fee, an analysis of benefits and services provided must be conducted. The Secretary must conduct an analysis on the benefits and services provided to visitors, the cumulative effect of the fee, costs and benefits to the Federal Government, public policy objectives, feasibility of fee collection, and other relevant factors before establishing fees for National Park units. This analysis must be submitted to Congress 90 days before the fee is published in the Federal Register. The Secretary must publish notices in the Federal Register for any new fee or changes in fee amounts established under this section. Fees and modifications will not take effect until 1 year after the publication date. The Secretary has the authority to waive or discount established fees.
